HSC BiologyFoundational

Skills Lab: Wet Mount Slides and Biological Diagrams

Learn how to prepare high-quality wet mount slides and draw biological diagrams that meet NESA standards‚Äîcore practical skills for HSC Biology and beyond.

üß™

üéØ LEARNING INTENTIONS

  • Students can safely prepare wet mount slides of plant and animal cells
  • Students can focus a light microscope and choose appropriate magnification
  • Students can construct biological diagrams that meet NESA conventions
  • Students can add scale bars and labels accurately to diagrams
  • Students can evaluate the quality of their own practical work

üîó KEY CONNECTIONS

  • Prior: Cell structure, microscope use, magnification calculations
  • Future: Practical investigations, first-hand data collection, exam drawing questions
  • Real World: Laboratory skills in research, pathology, and diagnostics
  • Skills: Following procedures, handling equipment, communicating visually

‚úÖ SUCCESS CRITERIA

  • I can prepare a safe, air-bubble-free wet mount slide
  • I can bring a specimen into focus at low and high power
  • I can draw a labelled diagram with correct proportions and no shading
  • I can calculate and include a scale bar on my diagram
  • I can annotate diagrams to explain structure-function relationships
üíß

Wet Mount Slides: Purpose and Principles

A wet mount slide is a temporary slide preparation where the specimen is suspended in a drop of liquid (usually water or stain) between a glass slide and a coverslip. Wet mounts are ideal for viewing living cells, fresh tissues, and small aquatic organisms.

üí° Key Concept: A good wet mount minimises air bubbles, keeps the specimen flat and thin, and prevents the sample from drying out. This improves image clarity and protects both the specimen and the microscope lens.
ComponentDescriptionFunction in Wet Mount
Glass slideRectangular glass sheetSupports specimen and coverslip; placed on stage
CoverslipThin square glass/plasticFlattens specimen; protects objective lens; reduces evaporation
Mounting mediumDrop of water or stainSuspends specimen; may stain structures for better contrast
SpecimenThin slice of tissue or single layer of cellsObject being observed and drawn
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistake: Thick specimens prevent light passing through and produce blurry images. Always use the thinnest possible sample‚Äîaim for a single cell layer when observing tissues like onion epidermis or cheek cells.
üîß

Step-by-Step: Preparing a Wet Mount (Onion Epidermis)

This procedure outlines how to prepare a classic onion epidermis wet mount to observe plant cells and their cell walls, nuclei, and vacuoles.

üßÖ

1. PREPARE THE TISSUE

Peel a thin, translucent layer of epidermis from the inside of an onion scale.

Tip: Use forceps to gently pull a very thin membrane‚Äîif it looks opaque or thick, discard and try again.
‚Üì
üíß

2. ADD WATER/STAIN

Place a small drop of water or iodine solution in the centre of a clean slide.

Iodine: Stains the nucleus and cell wall, increasing contrast so cells are easier to see.
‚Üì
üìç

3. POSITION THE SPECIMEN

Lay the onion epidermis flat in the drop using forceps. Ensure it is not folded or wrinkled.

Note: Gently smooth with a blunt needle if needed‚Äîavoid tearing the tissue.
‚Üì
ü™ü

4. LOWER THE COVERSLIP

Hold the coverslip at a 45¬∞ angle, one edge touching the liquid, then slowly lower it.

Goal: Push air out as the liquid spreads, minimising bubbles.

üìù Worked Example: Onion Epidermis Wet Mount

Question: Describe a method to prepare a wet mount of onion epidermis and explain how it avoids air bubbles and thick specimens.

Solution:

Step 1: Place a drop of water or iodine on a clean slide.
Step 2: Use forceps to peel a very thin piece of onion epidermis and place it flat in the drop.
Step 3: Hold the coverslip at about 45¬∞ with one edge touching the liquid, then lower it slowly so the liquid spreads and no air is trapped.
Step 4: Gently blot any excess stain around the coverslip with filter paper.

Explanation: Using a very thin epidermis ensures light can pass through and individual cells are visible. Lowering the coverslip at an angle pushes air out, reducing air bubbles that can obscure cells.

üö´ Exam Trap: Do not write 'put the coverslip on top' without describing the angled lowering technique. Marking criteria often require mentioning the 45¬∞ angle and avoiding air bubbles.
üßº

Safe Microscope Use and Focusing

Correct microscope technique prevents damage to equipment and ensures sharp images suitable for accurate biological drawings.

StepActionReason
1. TransportCarry the microscope with two hands: one on the arm, one under the base.Prevents dropping and damage to lenses and internal components.
2. SetupPlace on a flat bench, plug in, and switch on light.Stable platform prevents vibration and focus drift.
3. Start on low powerAlways begin with the lowest power objective (e.g. 4√ó).Wider field of view makes locating specimen easier and safer.
4. Coarse focus firstUse coarse focus only on low power.Prevents objective from crashing into slide on high power.
5. Centre specimenMove slide so specimen is centred before increasing magnification.Ensures specimen remains in view when FOV becomes smaller.
6. High power focusSwitch to higher power and use fine focus only.Fine focus gives sharp image without risking lens‚Äìslide contact.
7. Clean upLower stage, turn off light, unplug, and cover microscope.Protects microscope and prolongs lifespan.
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistake: Never use coarse focus with the 40√ó or 100√ó objective. This can crack the slide and damage the objective lens‚Äîa very expensive mistake.
‚úèÔ∏è

NESA-Standard Biological Diagrams

A biological diagram is a clear, labelled line drawing that represents observed specimens accurately and to scale. It is not artwork‚Äîits purpose is to communicate scientific information.

üí° NESA Conventions: Biological diagrams must be in pencil, use clear lines with no shading, include a descriptive title, have labels written horizontally in print, and show relative proportions accurately. Scale bars or magnification should be included whenever possible.

Key Features of a Good Biological Diagram

FeatureWhat to DoWhy It Matters
TitleWrite a clear title beneath the diagram (e.g. 'Diagram of Onion Epidermis Cells').Identifies what is shown; aligns with NESA requirement for clarity.
LinesUse single, sharp pencil lines. No sketching, no shading, no colouring.Avoids confusion; emphasises structure, not artistic style.
ProportionKeep shapes in correct proportion and orientation based on what you see.Ensures scientific accuracy; diagrams should reflect actual observation.
LabelsUse straight horizontal lines (rulers) leading to structures. Labels in print, not cursive.Improves readability and avoids overlapping lines.
ScaleInclude magnification or scale bar where possible.Allows others to understand actual size of structures.
Detail levelInclude only structures you actually observe at that magnification.Prevents adding imagined features; maintains integrity of observations.

üìù Worked Example: Onion Cell Diagram Checklist

Question: List features that must be included in a NESA-standard biological diagram of onion epidermis cells.

Model answer:

1. Use a sharp HB pencil and draw single, continuous lines for cell walls‚Äîno sketching or shading.
2. Draw several adjoining rectangular cells to show their arrangement, keeping sizes and shapes in proportion to what is seen.
3. Add straight, horizontal label lines with a ruler, labelling: cell wall, cytoplasm, nucleus, vacuole (if visible).
4. Write a descriptive title underneath the diagram, e.g. 'Diagram of Onion Epidermis Cells'.
5. Include either the magnification used (e.g. 'Observed at 400√ó') or a scale bar with a labelled length (e.g. 50 Œºm).
üö´ Exam Trap: Diagrams with shading, colour, or untidy sketch lines can lose marks even if the biology is correct. Keep diagrams clean, simple, and clearly labelled.
üìè

Scale Bars in Diagrams

A scale bar is a line drawn on a diagram that represents a specific actual distance (e.g. 10 Œºm). It allows anyone viewing the diagram to estimate sizes even without knowing the original magnification.

Key Idea: Use the magnification formula to calculate how long the scale bar should be on the page.

Steps:
1. Choose an actual length for the scale bar (e.g. 10 Œºm).
2. Multiply by magnification to find the image length (in Œºm or mm).
3. Draw a line of that length and label it (e.g. '10 Œºm').

Example: Magnification = √ó400, scale bar = 20 Œºm actual.
Image size = 20 Œºm √ó 400 = 8000 Œºm = 8 mm ‚Üí draw an 8 mm line and label '20 Œºm'.

üìù Worked Example: Designing a Scale Bar

Question: You drew an onion cell diagram based on observations at √ó400 magnification. You want to include a scale bar representing 50 Œºm. How long should the scale bar be on your page in mm?

Solution:

Step 1: Use Image Size = Actual Size √ó Magnification.
Step 2: Image size = 50 Œºm √ó 400 = 20,000 Œºm.
Step 3: Convert to mm: 20,000 Œºm √∑ 1000 = 20 mm.
Answer: Draw a 20 mm line and label it '50 Œºm'.

Check: At √ó400, 50 Œºm should appear 400√ó larger, so a length in the centimetre range is sensible.

üìã COPY INTO YOUR BOOKS

Wet Mount Slides

  • Wet mount = specimen in a drop of liquid under a coverslip
  • Use thin specimens so light can pass through
  • Lower coverslip at 45¬∞ to avoid air bubbles
  • Use water or stains (iodine, methylene blue) to increase contrast
  • Blot excess liquid with filter paper

Microscope Technique

  • Always start on low power (4√ó objective)
  • Use coarse focus on low power only
  • Centre specimen before increasing magnification
  • Use fine focus only on high power (40√ó objective)
  • Carry microscope with two hands; turn off and cover after use

Biological Diagrams

  • Use sharp pencil, single lines, no shading
  • Draw what you see, in correct proportion
  • Horizontal labels with ruler, printed text
  • Include descriptive title under diagram
  • Add magnification or scale bar where possible

Scale Bars

  • Scale bar shows actual distance (e.g. 20 Œºm)
  • Image length = actual length √ó magnification
  • Convert Œºm ‚Üî mm before drawing
  • Label the bar with actual length only
  • Check that scale bar matches diagram proportions

mcq.question: Which statement best describes how to lower a coverslip when preparing a wet mount?
options: Drop it straight down onto the specimen to trap it firmly
Lower it at a 45¬∞ angle so one edge touches the liquid first
Place it on the bench, then push it under the sample
Hold it vertically and press it onto the slide
mcq.explanation: Lowering the coverslip at a 45¬∞ angle allows the liquid to spread and pushes air out, reducing bubbles.

mcq.question: Which feature is NOT part of a NESA-standard biological diagram?
options: Single pencil lines with no shading
A clear, descriptive title below the diagram
Coloured shading to make the diagram look realistic
Straight horizontal label lines drawn with a ruler
mcq.explanation: Coloured shading is not part of NESA diagram conventions and can lose marks. Diagrams should be clear line drawings in pencil.

mcq.question: Why should coarse focus NOT be used with the high-power objective (e.g. 40√ó)?
options: It makes the field of view too bright
It can drive the objective lens into the slide and cause damage
It automatically changes the magnification
It turns off the microscope light
mcq.explanation: Coarse focus on high power can force the objective into the slide, cracking the glass and damaging the lens.

mcq.question: A student draws a neat onion cell diagram with correct labels but forgets to include a title. Which statement is most accurate?
options: The diagram is acceptable because titles are optional
The diagram will lose marks because all diagrams should have a clear title
Titles are only required for graphs, not diagrams
The title can be replaced by writing the magnification only
mcq.explanation: All biological diagrams should have a clear title so the reader knows exactly what is being shown.

mcq.question: A student wants to include a scale bar representing 40 Œºm on a diagram drawn from a √ó800 magnification image. How long should the scale bar be on the page?
options: 0.5 mm
32 mm
40 mm
mcq.explanation: Image size = Actual √ó Magnification = 40 Œºm √ó 800 = 32,000 Œºm = 32 mm. The bar should be 32 mm long.

saq.question: Describe the correct method for placing a coverslip when preparing a wet mount and explain why this method is used.
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Describe 45¬∞ angle with one edge touching liquid
1 mark: Describe slow lowering to spread liquid
1 mark: Explain it minimises air bubbles and protects specimen
saq.modelAnswer: Hold the coverslip at approximately 45¬∞ with one edge touching the drop of liquid on the slide. Slowly lower the coverslip so the liquid spreads underneath and air is pushed out in front of the coverslip. This method is used because it minimises trapping air bubbles, which can obscure the specimen, and helps the specimen lie flat in a thin, even layer, improving clarity and protecting the objective lens.

saq.question: Outline three conventions of a NESA-standard biological diagram and justify why each convention is important.
markingCriteria: 2 marks per convention: 1 for stating, 1 for justification (√ó3 conventions)
saq.modelAnswer: Convention 1: Use clear, single pencil lines with no shading. This makes structures easy to distinguish and avoids confusion caused by artistic effects. Convention 2: Labels should be written in printed text with straight, horizontal lines drawn using a ruler. This keeps the diagram tidy and ensures labels are easy to read and clearly associated with the correct structures. Convention 3: Include a descriptive title and either magnification or a scale bar. The title tells the reader exactly what specimen and view is shown, while the magnification/scale bar allows interpretation of actual size, making the diagram scientifically meaningful rather than just a picture.

saq.question: A diagram of a blood cell smear is drawn from an image taken at √ó1000 magnification. The student wants to draw a scale bar representing 10 Œºm. (a) Calculate how long the scale bar should be on the page in mm. (b) Explain why including a scale bar is useful for someone reading the diagram.
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Correct calculation (10 Œºm √ó 1000 = 10,000 Œºm = 10 mm)
1 mark: Correct units and final answer (10 mm)
1 mark: Explanation of scale bar utility
saq.modelAnswer: (a) Image size = Actual √ó Magnification = 10 Œºm √ó 1000 = 10,000 Œºm. Convert to mm: 10,000 Œºm √∑ 1000 = 10 mm. The scale bar should be 10 mm long. (b) A scale bar allows anyone viewing the diagram to estimate actual sizes even if they do not know the original magnification. It makes the diagram useful for quantitative comparisons, not just qualitative description.
